Context:
Program Name: Honours Bachelor of Brand Design
Code: G304
Credential: Honours Bachelor's Degree
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 4 years (8 semesters) plus 1 Co-op Work Term
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $7,807.00 *
International Tuition: $21,225.00 **
Program Location: Waterfront Campus
Centre: Arts, Design & Information Technology
School: Design
Program Description: The Honours Bachelor of Brand Design is a four-year degree program that prepares students to be forward-looking brand designers. It will give students the skills they need to succeed as a brand designer, including collaboration, research, strategic thinking, technical design execution, and brand storytelling.
Upon completing this program, you will:
- Convey a brand's identity through visual and physical designs across various online and offline platforms.
- Research and design adaptable brand experiences that engage customers across different touchpoints.
- Articulate a brand's story, connecting with audiences through various mediums.
- Foster innovative collaboration within diverse teams.
This program is eligible for a $1000 entrance scholarship.

* Domestic tuition fee for the 2023-2024 academic year
** International tuition fee for the 2023-2024 academic year
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Brand Design Program G304 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: The Brand Design program at George Brown College focuses on teaching students to create clear brand messages for various platforms, grasp new technology, write effectively for different scenarios and audiences, adapt to changing work environments, collaborate effectively, employ varied research methods in design, and provide diverse services. Students must complete a 420-hour paid co-op work term between their third and fourth year, which can be completed domestically and/or internationally. Notable training partners for the co-op program include agencies like Publicis, K9 Strategy + Design, Trevor/Peter, and Relish Interactive; larger brands such as Nelvana (Corus Entertainment), Rogers Media, Mozilla, and PUR Gum; and various industry-relevant arts and design institutions like the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF), the Association of Registered Graphic Designers (RGD), and Applied Arts. The School of Design is located in a new 103,000-square-foot facility in the Daniels Waterfront – City of the Arts development, featuring facilities such as virtual and augmented reality lab, usability and testing lab, Future Ways of Living lab, peer tutor lab, digital sandbox, incubators, prototyping and workshop spaces, and design and innovation showcase spaces.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Honours Bachelor of Brand Design Program G304 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text describes a co-op program at the School of Design of George Brown College. Students in this program can apply the skills they've acquired during their studies in a workplace environment or through an interaction design research project, gaining valuable experience and the opportunity to reflect on their learning. A faculty member evaluates students based on employer feedback. Students will develop a digital portfolio demonstrating completed artifacts from their work term.

Graduates of this program can expect careers in various fields including branding and digital media studios, creative labs, in-house design, and digital departments within larger corporations across sectors. Potential roles include brand designer, digital designer, user interface designer, design strategist, community manager, graphic designer, design researcher, storyteller/content writer, communications officer, marketing researcher, communication designer, content strategist, and positions in advertising, marketing, and public relations such as graphic designer or illustrator, content writer or web producer, communications specialist, marketing researcher, and business and strategy consultant.

Students who have completed the second or third year of George Brown College's Graphic Design Advanced Diploma (G102) with a grade point average of 3.2 (75 per cent) or higher may be eligible to enter a degree completion pathway to this program. Graduates of the Honours Bachelor of Brand Design program may qualify for further graduate studies in relevant areas.

The first semester required courses are:
- BDES 1005: History and Cultures of Branding (no prerequisites)
- BDES 1006: Introduction to Design Thinking (no prerequisites)
- BDES 1007: Design Studio 1: Design Foundations (no prerequisites)
- BDES 1008: Production 1: Print & Digital Applications (no prerequisites)
- BDES 1009: Type 1: Foundations (no prerequisites)
- BDES 1004: Communicating for (unclear, missing information)

Context:
The text provides information about the course offerings of a design program at the college. Here is the extracted information:

- There are six semesters in total.
- Semester 1 courses include "Communicating for Design" (BDES 1004), "Research for Design 1: Qualitative & Quantitative Foundations" (BDES 1204), "Design Studio 2: Design as Communication" (BDES 1205), "Production 2: Digital Applications" (BDES 1008), and a liberal studies elective.
- Semester 2 courses include "Brand Strategy 1: A to Z of the Brand" (BDES S2304), "Design Studio 3: Intro to 2D & 3D Design" (BDES 1205), "Production 3: Motion & Video" (BDES 1206), and a liberal studies elective.
- Semester 3 courses include "Brand Strategy 1: A to Z of the Brand" (BDES 2304), "Design Studio 3: Intro to 2D & 3D Design" (BDES 1205), "Production 3: Motion & Video" (BDES 2306), and a liberal studies elective.
- Semester 4 courses include "Critical Perspectives in Communications and Cultural Theory" (BDES 2404), "Research for Design 2: Qualitative Approaches and Tools" (BDES 1204), "Design Studio 4: Product & Packaging" (BDES 2407), and a liberal studies elective.
- Semester 5 courses include "Brand Strategy 2: Brand Resilience" (BDES 3506), "Research for Design 3: Data Collection and Analysis" (BDES 2405, BDES 2304), "Design Studio 5: UX/UI Branded Experiences" (BDES 3508), and a liberal studies elective.
- Semester 6 courses include "Brand Consumption in a Global Economy" (BDES 3606) and two other courses whose names are not mentioned in the text. The prerequisites for this course are "Critical Perspectives in Communications and Cultural Theory" (BDES 2404), "Brand Strategy 2: Brand Resilience" (BDES 3506), and another course whose name is not mentioned in the text.

Note that there are no mentions of specific years, emails, or names in the text.

Context:
Program Offered:
- BDES 2404, BDES 3507, BDES 3506, BDES 3607
- BDES 3507, BDES 3508, BDES 3509, BDES 3608
- BDES 4703, BDES 3506, BDES 4705, BDES 3607, BDES 3606
- BDES 4706
- GCOP 1001
- Prerequisites: BDES 4703, BDES 3506, BDES 4705, BDES 3606
- Senior Project I: Thesis Preparation
- Senior Project II: Thesis Development and Production
- Cross Platform Brand Narrative
- BDES 2408

Courses in Semester 7:
- Work-Integrated Learning Co-op (Code: GCOP 1001)

Courses in Semester 8:
- Intellectual Property (Code: BDES 4802)
- Cross Platform Brand Narrative

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Use ideation techniques to generate innovative design solutions that respond to a creative brief.
2. Participate in a collaborative brand-building project to produce an outcome that meets the needs of the client.
3. Incorporate interdisciplinary theoretical approaches in the planning, production, and critique of design and strategy work.
4. Plan, conduct and apply research in order to contextualize and make informed design.
5. Assess the social, environmental and economic impact of the design solution in order to prioritize sustainability issues in design practice.
6. Use the fundamental principles of branding to address the needs of the brand design and strategy for clients of various scale.
7. Design solutions in support of a brand strategy.
8. Communicate information, arguments, creative ideas and brand stories persuasively, to a range of audiences, using a variety of verbal, visual and written communication techniques.
9. Utilize professional practices and knowledge of the business of branding in all design and strategy work.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $7,807.00 * †
- International Tuition: $21,225

Context:
The text provides information about the tuition fees and admission requirements for a program at George Brown College. Here's the extracted information:

* Tuition for first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023: $7,807.00 (domestic), $21,225.00 (international)
* Additional costs: $21,225.00 (international students for programs starting in Fall 2024)
* Fees are subject to change and do not include books or the cost of work-integrated learning or co-op work term ($500) for international students
* The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria
* Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent with a combined average of 65 per cent or above (including English) and English, grade 12 (U) with a grade or 65 per cent or higher. Mature students can apply without an OSSD but must have English, grade 12 (U) with a grade of 65 per cent or higher and possibly post-secondary credits
* Qualified applicants will be invited to complete the application questionnaire and submit a portfolio electronically. Details on application questionnaire and portfolio requirements will be communicated at a later date.
* The information in the website is subject to change without notice and should not be considered as representation, offer or warranty. Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.

Context:
The text provides information on how to apply to George Brown College's School of Design, English language proficiency requirements, course exemptions, and contact details. Here is the extracted information:

- Applicants will be invited to complete an application questionnaire and submit a portfolio electronically. Details on these requirements will be communicated at a later date.
- Mature applicants need to have the English credit required and can find more information on upgrading on the English upgrading page.
- International applicants with international transcripts who do not provide English proficiency test results must test at the College level in the George Brown College English assessment for admission. More details can be found on the English Proficiency page.
- College or university credits may qualify students for course exemptions. More information can be found in the Transfer Guide.
- The consent from the Ministry of Colleges and Universities allows George Brown to offer this applied degree for a seven-year term starting March 6, 2020.
- International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System, while domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
- Contact information for the School of Design: Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 3129 and Email: design@georgebrown.ca. Additional contact details can be found on the International Contact Us page or by calling the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
- The School of Design is located at George Brown College's Waterfront Campus, at 3 Lower Jarvis St., Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
